data.text: Contents

Appendix 1: Morphine patient controlled analgesia (PCA)/nurse controlled analgesia (NCA) for paediatric pain management..............................................................................11 Appendix 2: Preliminary Equality Analysis..........................................................................12
Introduction

This guideline is designed to provide instruction and guidance for medical and nursing staff caring for patients with PCA (Patient Controlled Analgesia). The guideline also includes information relating to Nurse Controlled analgesia (NCA) which may be used in ITU settings or children's ward only, if appropriately trained staff in attendance
Scope of practice
These guidelines apply to registered nurses and prescribing anaesthetists responsible for the provision of PCA for pain management.
Patients assessed as requiring PCA/NCA as the optimum mode of pain management required will be cared for within the scope of this guideline
Estimated activity per annum: 300 PCA
24 hour cover by IPMS;
A prompt response service operates by pager system;
Clinical Nurse Specialists are available Monday to Friday, 8.00hrs to 17.00 hours and Saturday from 08.00 to 12.30 hours;
On-call service provided out of hours by anaesthetist;
3 consultant rounds per week;
Training and education provided by IPMS.
Definitions
Roles and responsibilities
Committee responsibilities:
Medicines Management Safety Group - maintenance of current and safe evidence based administration of drug
Pain Service Governance - monitoring and review of current evidence based clinical guidance
Individual responsibilities:
Prescribing clinician responsible for safe prescribing and administration of controlled drug via PCA
RNs responsible for safe management of patients receiving PCA , in line with Code of Practice Clause 4 to act in the patient's best interest and Clause  to be accountable for actions.
Procedures and monitoring
All PCAs / NCAs are schedule 2 controlled drugs and are prescribed by qualified medical staff or qualified independent prescriber.
The PCA / NCA programme is set and initiated by an anaesthetist, theatre recovery staff, critical care staff with appropriate skills, or a member of the IPMS.

Skill mix (i.e. appropriately trained nurses) and staffing levels on the ward are sufficient to ensure safe care of the patient. The nurse in charge must inform the anaesthetist or the IPMS prior to the start of the list if these criteria cannot be met.

The required level of acuity for PCA trained staff in any area or ward managing the care of these patients is 80%. Training is provided by the IPMS. The ward manager is responsible for liaising with the IPMS and allocating time for staff to attend training. Individual nurses are accountable for their own practice and maintaining competence in line with the NMC Code.

PCA / NCA is connected to the patient by qualified medical staff, the IPMS or any staff current in IV therapy skills. Blood or blood products are not to be infused through the PCA line, including the arm of the y-set extension.
Patient selection and informed verbal consent to PCA is part of the operation consent process. In non-surgical patients the device is explained by the attending IPMS clinician.
Analgesia
The common analgesic solution used for PCA / NCA within the Trust is:
MORPHINE 1mg per ml in 100mls of sodium chloride 0.9% (for use via IPMS approved infusion pump)
Alternatives are fentanyl 10mcgs per ml or oxycodone 1mg per ml IV or ketamine 1mg per ml. Ketamine may be used in isolation or added to the morphine infusion for PCA.
Ketamine PCA:
Morphine and ketamine PCA: add 100mg ketamine to infusion bag of 100mg morphine per 100ml saline.

Administration of ketamine via PCA to be initiated and prescribed by the IPMS only. Pain Consultants may increase the ratio of ketamine to morphine at their discretion after clinical assessment. Additional ketamine will then be added to the infusion bag as prescribed.
The common bolus dose for an adult is morphine 1mg with a 5 minute lockout. This remains the same with the addition of ketamine.
Children aged 5 and over may be prescribed a morphine PCA at the discretion of the anaesthetist or pain team (bolus 0.5mg or 1mg depending on body weight)
No other opioids are to be administered to the patient when the opioid PCA / NCA is in progress.
Patients receiving long term opioids prior to PCA / NCA commencement to be assessed by the anaesthetist pre-operatively if surgery is planned, and pain team informed.
Patient monitoring
The following monitoring is required:
Respiration rate
Pulse rate
Blood pressure
Sedation score (0 - 3),
Pain assessment (0 - 3)
Nausea and vomiting (n/v)
NEWS
When recording observations on the electronic records system for PCA
total / attempts are to be recorded as U (unmeasurable) as they are not required. This measurement has not shown to add clinical significance to pain assessment
Record at  minute intervals for first 2 hours, 30 minute intervals for next 2 hours,
then 1 - 2 hourly as clinically indicated. After 24 hours, 4 hourly observations may be agreed with senior ward staff as clinically appropriate.
The volume to be infused (VTBI) of the solution used must be recorded hourly as
read from the pump display
For patients receiving NCA, the amount of NCA delivered to be recorded and a running total of analgesia delivered must be easily accessible for review.
Cannula site is checked regularly.

The patient is seen at least once daily by the pain team to make a clinical assessment. The patient's progress and further management is discussed with the ward staff. Problems that arise at other times must be communicated to the IPMS. Outside office hours, the on-call ward doctor to be contacted for clinical problems. The on-call anaesthetist will provide expert/emergency cover.

NCA can only be used in the ITU setting, or on the children's ward with appropriate training. Once the patient is able to use the PCA this must be documented and prescription reviewed to conform to the Trust PCA prescription.
Patient who are assessed as requiring urgent clinical assessment evidenced by NEWS score are managed accordingly
Programme alterations
Alterations in the programme setting are done by an anaesthetist or a member of the IPMS, according to Trust protocol.

A clinician bolus to improve analgesia can be delivered via the PCA infusion device by anaesthetists and pain CNSs proficient in the management of the device. IV drug policy standards apply. Relevant specialist competencies must have been completed by the CNS.
Technical problems

Technical problems with the pump must be referred to the IPMS or on call anaesthetist as soon as possible. Replacement of the infusion bag or the batteries, when needed, to be done by the ward nurse as soon as possible to avoid detriment to the patient's pain control.
Discontinuation of the PCA
This is agreed with the patient in liaison with the IPMS, and appropriate alternative analgesia prescribed and offered.
Analgesic needs, following removal of PCA / NCA, to be assessed and evaluated regularly with the patient, and adjusted accordingly.
Any remaining PCA / NCA to be destroyed according to the Controlled Drugs policy MSEPO-20237.
Infection control
Hand hygiene policy for infection prevention to be adhered to according to Trust Policy.
Equipment to be cleaned between patients unless single use item which will be disposed of appropriately as per the Waste Management Policy.
Aprons and gloves to be worn as appropriate.
Non-Compliance with this guideline
Inappropriate use of the PCA / NCA which may lead to clinical complications:

Overuse – i.e. by persons other than the patient pressing the bolus button, may precipitate confusion, hallucinations, nausea and vomiting and convulsions. Respiratory depression related to opioid overuse may lead to respiratory arrest, loss of consciousness and death.

Underuse – i.e. withdrawal of, or inaccessibility to, the bolus facility or failure to address technical problems such as machine problems or empty chamber, may lead to uncontrolled pain and distress.

Unsolicited alteration of programme – any changes to delivery of PCA to be executed by IPMS or anaesthetist only, and prescribed and documented accordingly. This limits the risk of technical and clinical error and assures continuity of care through good communication.
An incident report must be completed for each event of non-compliance with this Guideline via the electronic incident reporting system.
Staff and training
This guideline is aimed at all registered nursing and medical staff.
Nursing staff managing patients receiving PCA / NCA infusions must have the appropriate knowledge and clinical skills to provide safe, evidence based care.

Training is provided within the Trust by the IPMS (Integrated Pain Management Service), and assessment of competency arranged with the pain link nurses, in order to achieve an overall competency level of 80% across the unit or ward.
A teaching programme for both medical and nursing staff is undertaken in liaison with the Training and Development department.
Audit and monitoring
Each patient receiving PCA / NCA will be assessed at least once daily by the Pain Team. Data recorded will be:
Patient satisfaction;
Pain levels;
Nausea;
Vomiting incidence;
Any adverse clinical events;
Incidence of non-compliance with the guideline;
Action taken.
Individual incidents of non-compliance are addressed by the Pain Service immediately, and risk assessments done as indicated.

Ensuring actions are undertaken by the Pain Service to ensure omissions and errors are brought to the attention of the appropriate person(s) and to reduce the risk of repeat: i.e. training and education of system reviews.

Data is entered onto a central database held by the Pain Service and evaluated yearly for trends at a departmental meeting. Dissemination of data via the appropriate forum (e.g. audit sessions, MDT), is the responsibility of the lead consultant of the IPMS
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 2)
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be circulated clinically and professional approval confirmed by the Pain Service Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform appropriate staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
References
DoH Essence of Care. Benchmarks for prevention and management of pain. October 2010
Acute Pain Management: www.painsociety.com
Intrurrisi C. Clinical Pharmacology of Opioids for Pain. Clinical Journal of Pain: Vol 18(4), July/August 2002.

Schwenk E, Viscusi ER, Buvanendran A, et al. Consensus guidelines on the use of intravenous ketamine infusions for acute pain management from the American Society of Regional Anesthesia and Pain Medicine (ASRA), American Academy of Pain Medicine (AAPM) and the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA). Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2018;43(5):456–466. https://doi.org/10.1097/AAP.0000000000000806
Radvansky BM, Puri S, Sifonios AN, Eloy JD, Le V. Ketamine—a narrative review of its uses in medicine. Am J Ther. 2016;23: e1414–e1426. https://doi.org/10.1097/MJT.0000000000000257

Cohen SP, Bhatia A, Buvanendran A, et al. Consensus guidelines on the use of intravenous ketamine infusions for chronic pain from the American Society of Regional Anesthesia and Pain Medicine (ASRA), the American Academy of Pain Medicine (AAPM), and the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA). Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2018;43(5):521–546. https://doi.org/10.1097/AAP.0000000000000808

data.url: 06010 Patient controlled analgesia guidelines integrated pain management 8.1.003.png

data.text: NURSE CONTROLLED ANALGESIA (NCA) FOR PAEDIATRIC PAIN MANAGEMENT
Setting up the PCA/NCA
Making up the Morphine filled bag

table_items.text: PCA/ NCA if the body weight <50kg
Morphine sulphate 1mg/kg made up to 50 mls with 0.9% sodium chloride=20mcg/kg/ml
PCA/ NCA if the body weight >50kgs
Morphine sulphate 100mgs made up to 100mls with 0.9% sodium chloride = 1mg/ml

data.text: Setting of the Morphine PCA/NCA pump
The dose will have to be titrated to effect after careful assessment, due to variability among children.
Background should only be continued for the first 24-48 hours or earlier if the analgesic requirement is less.

The PCA prescription and settings should be checked in recovery, when receiving the patient from post- operative care unit and at the beginning of each shift. The bag must be discarded every 24hours and the lines must be changed every 72 hrs.
The bag should be madeup only by the recovery nurses, Anaesthetic staff, pain team and pharmacy staff.
Appendix 2: Preliminary equality analysis
